standard_metadata.standard_description: Represent three-dimensional figures using nets made up of rectangles and triangles, and use the nets to find the surface area of these figures. Apply these techniques in the context of solving real-world and mathematical problems.

question.content: Check out this cube:     **Find the surface area of the cube (above) using its net (below).**       units$^2$

images.alt: A net on a coordinate grid.  The net consists of 6 squares. All of the squares have side lengths of 2 units. 4 of the squares are are in a row. There is a square connected to the top and a square connected to the bottom of the second square, each with side lengths of 2 units.
A cube with side lengths of 2 units.

hints.content: All  $6$ of the faces are squares.  >$\begin{align} \text{Area of a square} &=  \text{side} \cdot \text{side}\\\\ &= 2 \cdot 2\\\\ &= \blueD{4}\\\\ \end{align}$
>$\begin{align} \text{Surface area of a cube} &=  6 \cdot \blueD{\text{Area of a square}}\\\\ &= 6 \cdot \blueD{4}\\\\ &= 24 \end{align}$
**The surface area of this cube is $24$ units$^2$.**

question.content: Check out this cube:    **Find the surface area of the cube (above) using its net (below).**       units$^2$

images.alt: The figure presents a cube. The length of one edge is labeled as 3 units

The figure presents a surface net of a cube. The net consists of 4 squares connected in a row. The second square from the left is also connected to a square above it, and a square below it. The length of one side of one square is labeled as 3 units.

hints.content: All  $6$ of the faces are squares.  >$\begin{align} \text{Area of a square} &=  \text{side} \cdot \text{side}\\\\ &= 3\cdot3\\\\ &= \blueD{9}\\\\ \end{align}$
>$\begin{align} \text{Surface area of a cube} &=  6 \cdot \blueD{\text{Area of a square}}\\\\ &= 6 \cdot \blueD{9}\\\\ &= 54 \end{align}$
**The surface area of this cube is $54$ units$^2$.**

question.content: Check out this cube:    **Find the surface area of the cube (above) using its net (below).**       units$^2$

images.alt: The figure presents a cube. The length of one edge is labeled as 4 units

The figure presents a surface net of a cube. The net consists of 4 squares connected in a row. The second square from the left is also connected to a square above it, and a square below it. The length of one side of one square is labeled as 4 units.

hints.content: All  $6$ of the faces are squares.  >$\begin{align} \text{Area of a square} &=  \text{side} \cdot \text{side}\\\\ &= 4\cdot4\\\\ &= \blueD{16}\\\\ \end{align}$
>$\begin{align} \text{Surface area of a cube} &=  6 \cdot \blueD{\text{Area of a square}}\\\\ &= 6 \cdot \blueD{16}\\\\ &= 96 \end{align}$
**The surface area of this cube is $96$ units$^2$.**

question.content: Check out this cube:    **Find the surface area of the cube (above) using its net (below).**       units$^2$

images.alt: The figure presents a cube. The length of one edge is labeled as 5 units

The figure presents a surface net of a cube. The net consists of 4 squares connected in a row. The second square from the left is also connected to a square above it, and a square below it. The length of one side of one square is labeled as 5 units.

hints.content: All  $6$ of the faces are squares.  >$\begin{align} \text{Area of a square} &=  \text{side} \cdot \text{side}\\\\ &= 5 \cdot 5\\\\ &= \blueD{25}\\\\ \end{align}$
>$\begin{align} \text{Surface area of a cube} &=  6 \cdot \blueD{\text{Area of a square}}\\\\ &= 6 \cdot \blueD{25}\\\\ &= 150 \end{align}$
**The surface area of this cube is $150$ units$^2$.**

question.content: Check out this rectangular prism    **Find the surface area of the rectangular prism (above) using its net (below).**       units$^2$

images.alt: The figure presents a rectangular prism. The line connecting the left and right faces is labeled as 2 units. The line connecting the top and bottom faces is labeled as 3 units. The line connecting the front and back faces is labeled as 5 units.

The figure presents a surface net of a rectangular prism. The net consists of 4 rectangles in a row, where the second rectangle from the left is also connected to a rectangle above it and a rectangle below it. The bottom of the left most rectangle is labeled as 3 units. The bottom of the second rectangle from the left is labeled as 2 units. The right side of the second rectangle from the left is labeled as 5 units. The left side of the rectangle located beneath the second rectangle is labeled as 3 units.

hints.content: Each of the sides is a $5$ by $3$ rectangle.   >$\begin{align} \text{Area of a rectangle} &=  \text{length} \cdot \text{width}\\\\ &= 5 \cdot 3\\\\ &= {15} \\\\ \end{align}$  The total area of the sides  is $2 \cdot 15 = \blueD{30}$.

The bottom and the top are both $5$ by $2$ rectangles.  >$\begin{align} \text{Area of a rectangle} &=  \text{length} \cdot \text{width}\\\\ &= 5 \cdot 2\\\\ &= {10} \\\\ \end{align}$  The total area of the bottom and the top is $2 \cdot 10 = \greenD{20}$.

The back and the front are both $3$ by $2$ rectangles.   >$\begin{align} \text{Area of a rectangle} &=  \text{length} \cdot \text{width}\\\\ &= 3 \cdot 2\\\\ &= {6} \\\\ \end{align}$  The total area of the back and the front  is $2 \cdot 6 = \goldD{12}$.
Let's add the areas we found to find the surface area.  >$\begin{align} \text{Surface area} &= \blueD{30}+ \greenD{20} + \goldD{12} \\\\ &= 62\\\\ \end{align}$
**The surface area of this rectangular prism is $62$ units$^2$.**

question.content: Check out this rectangular prism     **Find the surface area of the rectangular prism (above) using its net (below).**        units$^2$

images.alt: A rectangular prism. The length is 5 units. The width is 2 units. The height is 2 units.

A net on a coordinate grid.  The net consists of 2 squares and 4 rectangles.  The 2 squares and 2 of the rectangles are connected by the short side.  The first square has side lengths of 2 units. The first rectangle has a base of 5 units and a height of 2 units. The second square has side lengths of 2 units. The second rectangle has a base of 5 units and a height of 2 units.  There is a rectangle connected to the top and a rectangle connected to the bottom of the second rectangle, each with a base of 5 units and a height of 2 units.

hints.content: Each of the sides is a $2$ by $2$ square.   >$\begin{align} \text{Area of a square} &=  \text{side} \cdot \text{side}\\\\ &= 2 \cdot 2\\\\ &= {4} \\\\ \end{align}$  The total area of the sides  is $2 \cdot 4 = \blueD{8}$.

The back, the front, the bottom and the top are all $2$ by $5$ rectangles.  >$\begin{align} \text{Area of a rectangle} &=  \text{length} \cdot \text{width}\\\\ &= 2 \cdot 5\\\\ &= {10} \\\\ \end{align}$  The total area of the back, the front, the bottom, and the top is $4 \cdot 10 = \greenD{40}$.
Let's add the areas we found to find the surface area.  >$\begin{align} \text{Surface area} &= \blueD{8}+ \greenD{40} \\\\ &= 48\\\\ \end{align}$
**The surface area of this rectangular prism is $48$ units$^2$.**

question.content: Check out this rectangular prism     **Find the surface area of the rectangular prism (above) using its net (below).**        units$^2$

images.alt: A rectangular prism. The length is 3 units. The width is 4 units. The height is 2 units.

A net on a coordinate grid.  The net consists of 6 rectangles.  4 of the rectangles are connected by the long side.  The first rectangle has a base of 2 units and a height of 4 units.  The second rectangle has a base of 3 units and a height of 4 units. The third rectangle has a base of 2 units and a height of 4 units.  The fourth rectangle has a base of 3 units and a height of 4 units. There is a rectangle connected to the top and a rectangle connected to the bottom of the second rectangle, each with a base of 3 units and a height of 2 units.

hints.content: Each of the sides is a $4$ by $2$ rectangle.   >$\begin{align} \text{Area of a rectangle} &=  \text{length} \cdot \text{width}\\\\ &= 4 \cdot 2\\\\ &= {8} \\\\ \end{align}$  The total area of the sides  is $2 \cdot 8 = \blueD{16}$.

The bottom and the top are both $4$ by $3$ rectangles.  >$\begin{align} \text{Area of a rectangle} &=  \text{length} \cdot \text{width}\\\\ &= 4 \cdot 3\\\\ &= {12} \\\\ \end{align}$  The total area of the bottom and the top is $2 \cdot 12 = \greenD{24}$.

The back and the front are both $2$ by $3$ rectangles.   >$\begin{align} \text{Area of a rectangle} &=  \text{length} \cdot \text{width}\\\\ &= 2 \cdot 3\\\\ &= {6} \\\\ \end{align}$  The total area of the back and the front  is $2 \cdot 6 = \goldD{12}$.
Let's add the areas we found to find the surface area.  >$\begin{align} \text{Surface area} &= \blueD{16}+ \greenD{24} + \goldD{12} \\\\ &= 52\\\\ \end{align}$
**The surface area of this rectangular prism is $52$ units$^2$.**

question.content: Check out this rectangular prism     **Find the surface area of the rectangular prism (above) using its net (below).**          units$^2$

images.alt: A rectangular prism. The length is 7 units. The width is 2 units. The height is 3 units.

A net on a coordinate grid.  The net consists of 6 rectangles.  4 of the rectangles are connected by the short side.  The first rectangle has a base of 3 units and a height of 2 units.  The second rectangle has a base of 7 units and a height of 2 units. The third rectangle has a base of 3 units and a height of 2 units.  The fourth rectangle has a base of 7 units and a height of 2 units. There is a rectangle connected to the top and a rectangle connected to the bottom of the second rectangle, each with a base of 7 units and a height of 3 units.

hints.content: Let's completely label the net of the rectangular prism.  [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt: A net of a rectangular prism.  The net consists of 6 rectangles.  4 of the rectangles are connected by the short side.  The first rectangle, labeled side, has a base of 3 units and a height of 2 units.  The second rectangle, labeled bottom, has a base of 7 units and a height of 2 units. The third rectangle, labeled side, has a base of 3 units and a height of 2 units.  The fourth rectangle, labeled top, has a base of 7 units and a height of 2 units. There is a rectangle connected to the top, labeled back, and a rectangle connected to the bottom, labeled front, of the second rectangle, each with a base of 7 units and a height of 3 units.

hints.content: Each of the sides is a $2$ by $3$ rectangle.   >$\begin{align} \text{Area of a rectangle} &=  \text{length} \cdot \text{width}\\\\ &= 2 \cdot 3\\\\ &= {6} \\\\ \end{align}$  The total area of the sides  is $2 \cdot 6 = \blueD{12}$.

The bottom and the top are both $2$ by $7$ rectangles.  >$\begin{align} \text{Area of a rectangle} &=  \text{length} \cdot \text{width}\\\\ &= 2 \cdot 7\\\\ &= {14} \\\\ \end{align}$  The total area of the bottom and the top is $2 \cdot 14 = \greenD{28}$.

The back and the front are both $3$ by $7$ rectangles.   >$\begin{align} \text{Area of a rectangle} &=  \text{length} \cdot \text{width}\\\\ &= 3 \cdot 7\\\\ &= {21} \\\\ \end{align}$  The total area of the back and the front  is $2 \cdot 21 = \goldD{42}$.
Let's add the areas we found to find the surface area.  >$\begin{align} \text{Surface area} &= \blueD{12}+ \greenD{28} + \goldD{42} \\\\ &= 82\\\\ \end{align}$
**The surface area of this rectangular prism is $82$ units$^2$.**

question.content: Check out this triangular prism:      **Find the surface area of the triangular prism (above) using its net (below).**        units$^2$

images.alt: A triangular prism. The bottom face has side lengths of 6 units and 7 units. The other 2 faces have side lengths of 5 units and 7 units. The triangular prism has a height of 4 units.

A net on a coordinate grid.  The net consists of 3 rectangles and 2 triangles.  The rectangles are connected by the long side.  The first rectangle has a base of 5 units and a height of 7 units.  The second rectangle has a base of 6 units and a height of 7 units. The third rectangle has a base of 5 units and a height of 7 units.  There is a triangle connected to the top and bottom of the second rectangle.  Each right triangle has a base of 6 units and a height of 4 units.

hints.content: $2$ of the faces are $7$ by $5$ rectangles.   >$\begin{align} \text{Area of a rectangle} &=  \text{length} \cdot \text{width}\\\\ &= 7 \cdot 5\\\\ &= {35} \\\\ \end{align}$  The total area of these $2$ rectangles  is $2 \cdot 35 = \blueD{70}$.
$1$ of the faces is a $7$ by $6$ rectangle.  >$\begin{align} \text{Area of a rectangle} &=  \text{length} \cdot \text{width}\\\\ &= 7 \cdot 6\\\\ &= {\greenD{42}} \\\\ \end{align}$

$2$ of the faces are triangles. Each triangle has the same base and height.  >$\begin{align} \text{Area of a triangle} &=  \dfrac12 \cdot \text{base} \cdot \text{height}\\\\ &= \dfrac12 \cdot 6 \cdot 4\\\\ &= 12 \\\\ \end{align}$   The total area of these $2$ triangles is $2 \cdot 12 = \goldD{24}$.
Let's add the areas we found to find the surface area.  >$\begin{align} \text{Surface area} &= \blueD{70}+ \greenD{42} + \goldD{24} \\\\ &= 136\\\\ \end{align}$
**The surface area of this triangular prism is $136$ units$^2$.**

question.content: Check out this triangular prism:     **Find the surface area of the triangular prism (above) using its net (below).**        units$^2$

images.alt: A triangular prism. The bottom face has side lengths of 6 units and 7 units. The other 2 faces have side lengths of 3 units and 7 units. The triangular prism has a height of 2 units.

A net on a coordinate grid.  The net consists of 3 rectangles and 2 triangles.  The rectangles are connected by the long side.  The first rectangle has a base of 3 units and a height of 7 units.  The second rectangle has a base of 6 units and a height of 7 units. The third rectangle has a base of 3 units and a height of 7 units.  There is a triangle connected to the top and bottom of the second rectangle.  Each right triangle has a base of 6 units and a height of 2 units.

hints.content: $2$ of the faces are $7$ by $3$ rectangles.   >$\begin{align} \text{Area of a rectangle} &=  \text{length} \cdot \text{width}\\\\ &= 7 \cdot 3\\\\ &= {21} \\\\ \end{align}$  The total area of these $2$ rectangles  is $2 \cdot 21 = \blueD{42}$.
$1$ of the faces is a $7$ by $6$ rectangle.  >$\begin{align} \text{Area of a rectangle} &=  \text{length} \cdot \text{width}\\\\ &= 7 \cdot 6\\\\ &= {\greenD{42}} \\\\ \end{align}$

$2$ of the faces are triangles. Each triangle has the same base and height.  >$\begin{align} \text{Area of a triangle} &=  \dfrac12 \cdot \text{base} \cdot \text{height}\\\\ &= \dfrac12 \cdot 6 \cdot 2\\\\ &= 6 \\\\ \end{align}$   The total area of these $2$ triangles is $2 \cdot 6 = \goldD{12}$.
Let's add the areas we found to find the surface area.  >$\begin{align} \text{Surface area} &= \blueD{42}+ \greenD{42} + \goldD{12} \\\\ &= 96\\\\ \end{align}$
**The surface area of this triangular prism is $96$ units$^2$.**

question.content: Check out this right triangular prism:      **Find the surface area of the right triangular prism (above) using its net (below).**         units$^2$

images.alt: A right triangular prism. The bottom face has side lengths of 4 units and 11 units. The side face has side lengths of 3 units and 11 units. The diagonal side face has side lengths of 5 units and 11 units. The triangular prism has a height of 3 units.

A net on a coordinate grid.  The net consists of 3 rectangles and 2 right triangles.  The rectangles are connected by the long side.  The first rectangle has a base of 3 units and a height of 11 units.  The second rectangle has a base of 4 units and a height of 11 units. The third rectangle has a base of 5 units and a height of 11 units.  There is a right triangle connected to the top and bottom of the second rectangle.  Each right triangle has a base of 4 units and a height of 3 units.

hints.content: $1$ of the faces is an $11$ by $3$ rectangle.  >$\begin{align} \text{Area of a rectangle} &=  \text{length} \cdot \text{width}\\\\ &= 11 \cdot 3\\\\ &= {\blueD{33}} \\\\ \end{align}$
$1$ of the faces is an $11$ by $4$ rectangle.  >$\begin{align} \text{Area of a rectangle} &=  \text{length} \cdot \text{width}\\\\ &= 11 \cdot 4\\\\ &= {\greenD{44}} \\\\ \end{align}$
$1$ of the faces is an $11$ by $5$ rectangle.  >$\begin{align} \text{Area of a rectangle} &=  \text{length} \cdot \text{width}\\\\ &= 11 \cdot 5\\\\ &= {\goldD{55}} \\\\ \end{align}$

$2$ of the faces are triangles. Each triangle has the same base and height.  >$\begin{align} \text{Area of a triangle} &=  \dfrac12 \cdot \text{base} \cdot \text{height}\\\\ &= \dfrac12 \cdot 4 \cdot 3\\\\ &= 6 \\\\ \end{align}$   The total area of these $2$ triangles is $2 \cdot 6 = \maroonD{12}$.
Let's add the areas we found to find the surface area.  >$\begin{align} \text{Surface area} &= \blueD{33}+ \greenD{44} + \goldD{55} + \maroonD{12} \\\\ &= 144\\\\ \end{align}$
**The surface area of this triangular prism is $144$ units$^2$.**

question.content: Check out this right triangular prism:    **Find the surface area of the right triangular prism (above) using its net (below).**         units$^2$

images.alt: A right triangular prism. The bottom face has side lengths of 4 units and 7 units. The side face has side lengths of 3 units and 7 units. The diagonal side face has side lengths of 5 units and 7 units. The triangular prism has a height of 3 units.

A net on a coordinate grid.  The net consists of 3 rectangles and 2 right triangles.  The rectangles are connected by the long side.  The first rectangle has a base of 3 units and a height of 7 units.  The second rectangle has a base of 4 units and a height of 7 units. The third rectangle has a base of 5 units and a height of 7 units.  There is a right triangle connected to the top and bottom of the second rectangle.  Each right triangle has a base of 4 units and a height of 3 units.

hints.content: $1$ of the faces is a $5$ by $7$ rectangle.  >$\begin{align} \text{Area of a rectangle} &=  \text{length} \cdot \text{width}\\\\ &= 5 \cdot 7\\\\ &= {\blueD{35}} \\\\ \end{align}$
$1$ of the faces is a $4$ by $7$ rectangle.  >$\begin{align} \text{Area of a rectangle} &=  \text{length} \cdot \text{width}\\\\ &= 4 \cdot 7\\\\ &= {\greenD{28}} \\\\ \end{align}$
$1$ of the faces is a $3$ by $7$ rectangle.  >$\begin{align} \text{Area of a rectangle} &=  \text{length} \cdot \text{width}\\\\ &= 3 \cdot 7\\\\ &= {\goldD{21}} \\\\ \end{align}$

$2$ of the faces are triangles. Each triangle has the same base and height.  >$\begin{align} \text{Area of a triangle} &=  \dfrac12 \cdot \text{base} \cdot \text{height}\\\\ &= \dfrac12 \cdot 4 \cdot 3\\\\ &= 6 \\\\ \end{align}$   The total area of these $2$ triangles is $2 \cdot 6 = \maroonD{12}$.
Let's add the areas we found to find the surface area.  >$\begin{align} \text{Surface area} &= \blueD{35}+ \greenD{28} + \goldD{21} + \maroonD{12} \\\\ &= 96\\\\ \end{align}$
**The surface area of this triangular prism is $96$ units$^2$.**

question.content: Check out this square pyramid:     **Find the surface area of the square pyramid (above) using its net (below).**        units$^2$

images.alt: A square pyramid.  The side of the pyramid's base is 5 units long and the height of the triangular face measured from the center of the side of base to the apex is 4 units.

A net on a coordinate grid.  The net consists of a square and 4 isosceles triangles. The square has a base of 5 units and a height of 5 units. Each triangle has a base of 5 units and a height of 4 units.

hints.content: $1$ of the faces is a square.  >$\begin{align} \text{Area of a square} &=  \text{side} \cdot \text{side}\\\\ &= 5 \cdot 5\\\\ &= {\blueD{25}} \\\\ \end{align}$

$4$ of the faces are triangles. Each triangle has the same base and height.  >$\begin{align} \text{Area of a triangle} &=  \dfrac12 \cdot \text{base} \cdot \text{height}\\\\ &= \dfrac12 \cdot 5 \cdot 4\\\\ &= 10 \\\\ \end{align}$   The total area of these $4$ triangles is $4 \cdot 10 = \greenD{40}$.
Let's add the areas we found to find the surface area.  >$\begin{align} \text{Surface area} &= \blueD{25}+ \greenD{40}\\\\ &= 65\\\\ \end{align}$
**The surface area of this square pyramid is $65$ units$^2$.**

question.content: Check out this square pyramid:     **Find the surface area of the square pyramid (above) using its net (below).**          units$^2$

images.alt: A square pyramid.  The side of the pyramid's base is 2 units long and the height of the triangular face measured from the center of the side of base to the apex is 2 units.

A net on a coordinate grid.  The net consists of a square and 4 isosceles triangles. The square has a base of 2 units and a height of 2 units. Each triangle has a base of 2 units and a height of 2 units.

hints.content: $1$ of the faces is a square.  >$\begin{align} \text{Area of a square} &=  \text{side} \cdot \text{side}\\\\ &= 2 \cdot 2\\\\ &= {\blueD{4}} \\\\ \end{align}$

$4$ of the faces are triangles. Each triangle has the same base and height.  >$\begin{align} \text{Area of a triangle} &=  \dfrac12 \cdot \text{base} \cdot \text{height}\\\\ &= \dfrac12 \cdot 2 \cdot 2\\\\ &= 2 \\\\ \end{align}$   The total area of these $4$ triangles is $4 \cdot 2 = \greenD{8}$.
Let's add the areas we found to find the surface area.  >$\begin{align} \text{Surface area} &= \blueD{4}+ \greenD{8}\\\\ &= 12\\\\ \end{align}$
**The surface area of this square pyramid is $12$ units$^2$.**

question.content: Check out this square pyramid:    **Find the surface area of the square pyramid (above) using its net (below).**         units$^2$

images.alt: A square pyramid.  The side of the pyramid's base is 4 units long and the height of the triangular face measured from the center of the side of base to the apex is 3 units.

A net on a coordinate grid.  The net consists of a square and 4 isosceles triangles. The square has a base of 4 units and a height of 4 units. Each triangle has a base of 4 units and a height of 3 units.

hints.content: $1$ of the faces is a square.  >$\begin{align} \text{Area of a square} &=  \text{side} \cdot \text{side}\\\\ &= 4 \cdot 4\\\\ &= {\blueD{16}} \\\\ \end{align}$

$4$ of the faces are triangles. Each triangle has the same base and height.  >$\begin{align} \text{Area of a triangle} &=  \dfrac12 \cdot \text{base} \cdot \text{height}\\\\ &= \dfrac12 \cdot 4 \cdot 3\\\\ &=6 \\\\ \end{align}$   The total area of these $4$ triangles is $4 \cdot 6 = \greenD{24}$.
Let's add the areas we found to find the surface area.  >$\begin{align} \text{Surface area} &= \blueD{16}+ \greenD{24}\\\\ &= 40\\\\ \end{align}$
**The surface area of this square pyramid is $40$ units$^2$.**

question.content: Check out this square pyramid:    **Find the surface area of the square pyramid (above) using its net (below).**         units$^2$

images.alt: A square pyramid.  The side of the pyramid's base is 3 units long and the height of the triangular face measured from the center of the side of base to the apex is 4 units.

A net on a coordinate grid.  The net consists of a square and 4 isosceles triangles. The square has a base of 3 units and a height of 3 units. Each triangle has a base of 3 units and a height of 4 units.

hints.content: $1$ of the faces is a square.  >$\begin{align} \text{Area of a square} &=  \text{side} \cdot \text{side}\\\\ &= 3 \cdot 3\\\\ &= {\blueD{9}} \\\\ \end{align}$

$4$ of the faces are triangles. Each triangle has the same base and height.  >$\begin{align} \text{Area of a triangle} &=  \dfrac12 \cdot \text{base} \cdot \text{height}\\\\ &= \dfrac12 \cdot 3 \cdot 4\\\\ &= 6 \\\\ \end{align}$   The total area of these $4$ triangles is $4 \cdot 6 = \greenD{24}$.
Let's add the areas we found to find the surface area.  >$\begin{align} \text{Surface area} &= \blueD{9}+ \greenD{24}\\\\ &= 33\\\\ \end{align}$
**The surface area of this square pyramid is $33$ units$^2$.**
